content.description: the confident beginner will find him or herself 15 feet up in approach shoes before they remember their chalk bag is still on the ground, but top out anyway. slightly downward sloping knobs and horizontal cracks are the nombre del juego here, can (and should) be climbed many ways
content.protection: a partial bag of chalk and shoes with rubber remaining should suffice
content.location: far left face of boulder, the ladder like features of horizontal cracks

climbs.name: Half man, half bear, half deranged Skagwegian youth

content.description: this beauty is a short hand and fist crack featuring your typical skagway munge and the occasional xenolith
content.location: "left ski track" of the small car sized block wedged in the middle of the wall, right of Soapy Smith Memorial Route- it is possible to traverse between the two on a series of juggy finger locks and bomber feet

content.description: crux is final moves. majority of the crack is thin hands with a section of flared, shallow fists towards the top and a final flared finger lock. top can feel a bit desperate, sometimes you just have to give'r
content.location: obvious vertical crack shrouded under the tree right of H.M.H.B.H.D.S.Y. V-Fun!

content.description: This cheeky little pebble provides excellent granite climbing maxing out at an elevation of approximately 40 feet. There are an assortment of engaging highballs or solos (top-roping may be possible but is never recommended, bring copious yardage of webbing to sling 'round trees if feeling sacrilegious) ranging from low commitment traverses to easily down-climbable face and crack with slab climbs. Bring your best array of sticks to brush lichen and spiderwebs out of the desired cracks and holds.
